I.  THE ONGOING PROGRAM 
 
1.  The microfinance risk participation and guarantee program (MFP), approved in 2010, fills 
a market gap by sharing risks with accredited partner financial institutions (PFIs) to facilitate local 
currency lending to the microfinance sector. Due to the program’s success and increased market 
demand, the ADB’s Board of Directors removed the program expiration date and included it into 
ADB’s mainstream operations in 2015. An additional program limit of $100 million (bringing the 
program’s overall limit to $340 million) and major change in scope for the program was approved 
by ADB’s Board of Directors on 13 December 2017.1 To expand the program into different 
countries with microfinance sectors at varying levels of maturity and to continue to facilitate 
funding to MFIs in existing countries varying strategies and broader product offerings are required.  
Primarily this will be through supporting microfinance institutions (MFIs) (i) to access domestic 
capital markets and (i) to increase their financial services range. It will also require broadening 
the type of PFIs to work with. As of end December 2017, the program has supported $638 million 
of  new  local  currency  loans  (including  cofinancing  of  $336  million),  reaching  3.49  million 
borrowers, mostly women.  
 
2.  With the increased limit and the introduction of new products, ADB plans to expand further 
in the region and support MFIs in diversifying their funding sources and product offerings to reach 
more of the unbanked population in Asia and the Pacific. ADB recently accredited Maybank as a 
new PFI for Myanmar and is in the process to accredit a new PFI for Sri Lanka. The program is 
also looking to expand to Pakistan in 2018.  To support these ongoing initiatives, a transaction 
technical assistance cluster (TRTA) in the amount of $2.0 million was approved in December 
2017. The first subproject in the amount of $500,000 was also approved in December 2017. 
Several consultant positions to support the expansion and the MFP team have been advertised. 
Guarantee and capital markets experts will start in April 2018 and a transaction support analyst 
will start in May 2018. The expansion and implementation of new products will be further 
supported through the technical assistance (TA), Subproject 2. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECT 
 
A.  Overall Progress of the Technical Assistance Cluster 
 
3.  This is the second subproject under the Microfinance Risk Participation and Guarantee 
Program Transaction Support for Expansion. 
 
B.  Subproject Scope  
 
4.  The cluster TA has as its overall outcome: sustainable financial inclusion increased. 
Through a combination of funding instruments, MFIs will receive more financing for lending to the 
lower income people who are predominately women, and PFIs will be more comfortable to lend 
directly to this market segment. To enable MFIs to diversify their funding sources and product 
offerings, this subproject will support guarantee and risk participation product readiness to credit 
enhance  bonds  and  securitizations  issued  by  MFIs.  It  will  also  support  identification  and 
onboarding of new MFIs on a needs basis, and evaluation of potential new PFIs. The subproject 
                                                
1  ADB. 2017. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Guarantee and 
Unfunded Risk Participation Products for Additional Financing for Microfinance Risk Participation and Guarantee 
Program. Manila

2   
will also include some contingency consulting budget to flexibly address upcoming needs during 
implementation. 
 
C.  Subproject Outputs and Activities  
 
5.  Output 1: Identification, evaluation and preparation of potential new PFIs and MFIs to be 
accredited under the MFP, including capacity building as needed. This will include legal support 
for (i) analysis of legal and regulatory environments in a new country, (ii) support to the MFP in 
the onboarding process of a new PFI, (iii) preparation of legal documentation and agreements, 
and  (iv)  international  legal  expertise  for  capital  market  transactions.  In  addition,  it  will  be 
necessary to support the MFP in the evaluation of potential new MFIs for the program.  It is 
estimated that ADB will include 10-15 more MFIs in the program in the next two years. The 
increased number of transactions and volume will also require support in integrity due diligence, 
portfolio  monitoring  and  reporting,  program  administration  and  communications.  One  legal 
consultant, one financial analyst, one transactions support analyst and one legal firm on a retainer 
basis will be needed. If necessary, the input will be complemented by an MFI and banking expert 
to assist in due diligence preparation and capacity building of PFIs.  
 
5.  Output  2:  Identification,  evaluation,  structuring  and  preparation  of  capital  market 
instruments and other guarantee/risk participation products to be guaranteed under the MFP. 
Assist in the identification, evaluation, structuring and preparation of capital market instruments 
and other guarantee/risk participation products to be guaranteed under the MFP.  To further 
complement  and  support  the  implementation  readiness  of  the  new  guarantee  and  risk 
participation products, it will be necessary to identify suitable loss estimation models that are 
applicable for securitization transactions. Initially, there will be a small number of securitizations.  
ADB may therefore rely on a few external providers (such as a rating agency) for estimation of 
losses and subsequent ratings of the underlying portfolio. A firm will be required to evaluate the 
different tools and validate 1 to 2 options. As necessary, the guarantee or capital market experts 
input might have to be extended. 
 
6.  Output 3: Disseminating sector information and other knowledge products to a broader 
audience. With the expansion of the MFP it will be important to apprise stakeholders on expansion 
activities, sector information and performance highlights. This will be achieved through a range of 
activities, such as website updates, blogs and other media promotions. Awareness activities for 
the program and particularly for the new guarantee products (structures, evaluations techniques, 
risk assessments) will be disseminated to a broader audience, such as ADB’s financial sector 
group and other external stakeholders2 through a series of workshops. 
 
D.  Subproject Cost and Financing 
7.  The TA subproject is estimated to cost $1,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-Others). The funds will cover remuneration, 
travel,  and  per  diem  for  international  consultants,  conference  related  expenditures,  and 
miscellaneous expenses.  
 
E.  Subproject Implementation Arrangements 
8.  ADB will administer Subproject 2 and its Private Sector Operations Department, Financial 
Institutions Division, will select, supervise and evaluate consultants.
